article.headline: Bourbon that tastes like cold-brew coffee â the perfect drink for 2020?
article.body: FEW Spirits founder Paul Hletko says Cold Cut Bourbon has 'layers upon layers of flavor and nuance.' FEW Spirits The bottle: FEW Spirits Cold Cut Bourbon, $44.99 The back story: Itâs no secret that we love our bourbon â sales of the classic American-made whiskey hit an all-time high of $1.78 billion in 2019. And we also love our coffee, with the cold-brew style gaining in popularity of late. So itâs perhaps inevitable that some enterprising spirits company would finally combine the two sips into one. That company is FEW, an Illinois-based distillery that started almost a decade ago, making just a few cases (hence, the name, though the company also notes, with tongue-in-cheek, that F.E.W. are the initials of Frances Elizabeth Willard, a pioneer of the temperance movement). FEW founder Paul Hletko points out that coffee-flavored spirits are hardly anything new, but he says that Cold Cut Bourbon represents a different idea. Itâs really about the bourbon, which, like much whiskey, is produced at a potent level â aka cask strength â and then cut with liquid to bring it down to something easier to drink. Typically, that liquid is water, but FEW decided to experiment with using cold-brew coffee. The result is Cold Cut Bourbon, a sip that Hlekto says has âlayers upon layers of flavor and nuance.â Since the bottleâs release almost a year ago, it has become a strong seller for FEW, especially of late. Monthly sales have averaged 30% growth since April, the company says. What we think about it: This is a one-of-a-kind bourbon â and a tasty one to boot. Itâs a smooth sip â you get a mouthful of what FEW rightly describes as âcorn sweetness and oak,â but the coffee is decidedly there in the background, adding richness and spice. The bottle is so unique that weâd hesitate to call it your everyday go-to bourbon, but itâs definitely one worth trying. How to enjoy it: The FEW team suggests this is a perfect after-dinner drink â when itâs too late for a cup of coffee and you âdonât necessary want dessert.â Itâs perhaps too boozy (93 proof) as an alternative to your morning cup. Then again, if you want a strong drink in the morning, FEW also makes a Breakfast Gin.
